A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name: Mrs. Mary A. Bornholdt

2. Your address: Princess Place, Weyburn, Saskatchewan

3. Date: May 26th, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Bloomingdale, Montana County

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Michael Hassel - Farmer

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June 1899

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: I always lived in the same place in Canada

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West? There was a great opening to get a homestead for ten dollars ($10) stock allowed money. I could get land working on factories. I could get railroad work.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Mary A. Bornholdt
2. Your address: Regina, Saskatchewan
3. Date: May 26th, 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Blomberg, Germany
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Michael Hassel
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June 1879
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: I always lived in the same place in Canada
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," if you were in my teens, etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West? There was a great opening to get a homestead for ten dollars ($10) which attracted many people who got land warrants.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) Through other people.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They did not like the idea of coming west.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelled by myself and met others.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I came west by train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

It was a long, tiring journey, no little and a single seat. I had to sit up most of the time or I could let my legs fall. The train was very slow and I could not get any sleep.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I stayed at Indian Head for a year.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Yellow Grass, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No other places but Yellow Grass - always had faith in the country even in the dry years when we went through a lot of hardship.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

How, after you came?
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They did not like the idea of coming west.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

I traveled by myself and my child.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

I came west by train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

It was a long, tiring journey. We had to travel through snow and a single road. I had to carry most of the time or I could let my little baby lie down. I carried my own bundle which got pretty stale.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I stayed at Indian Head for a year.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Yellow Grass, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

It's been places like Yellow Grass... always hard work.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

How often you came?

Have always been a house helper.

I did not travel about much. The homestead was far from town, so attending church, visiting friends, we walked mostly about five miles.
